body:
MCU Headcanon #12

Peter kept the Hello Kitty pajama pants Tony gave him in the back of his closet as a reminder that he is Spider-Man, not the suit. After Tony’s death, he pulls them on, clutching his suit to his chest and cries his eyes out, wishing the he wasn’t Spider-Man and it was just his suit.

by CarolDanversWives

Y/N is trying to survive his new school, filled with super-powered kids.
Peter is trying to deal with the voices in his head.
Pietro wants to kick his drug habits.
Love ensues as their paths cross.

Our first fic!

summary: Unpopular Opinion , but do people rlly think pepper is gonna become peters mother figure just bc Tony was his "father figure" ?...
body: Unpopular Opinion , but do people rlly think pepper is gonna become peters mother figure just bc Tony was his “father figure” ? Like just stop , peter has a mother and her name is May Parker, stop trying to ignore that he has her just to throw in your shitty headcanons

blog.name: iloveyouthree-thousand
blog.title: Peter You Outshine the Morning Sun, My Son
blog.description: My inbox is always open for requests / prompts / whatever your heart desires.

tags: not quite sure where this came from
summary: a suit of armor around (his) world
title: a suit of armor around (his) world
body:
Pepper finds Peter on the dock, feet dangling over the wooden planks, staring out across the water. 

“Hey,” she says softly, smiling gently as she claims the spot next to him, “what’re you doing out here?”

“Hm,” he hums, “thinking, I guess.”

“About what?”

She asks the question even though she already knows the answer. She knows exactly where his mind is as his gaze fixes over the horizon.

“Just,” he shrugs, gesturing out in to the wind, “y’know. About all of it.”

Her fingers trace gently across his shoulder blades in an action she’d seen Tony do many times before, the sensation both strange and familiar on Peter’s skin. 

“He always thought that you’d like it out here. He said that that brain of yours,” her fingers tap lightly on his forehead, “had a habit of getting a little too loud sometimes. You remind me of him, in a lot of ways.“

They let the trickle of the evening waves fill the air for a moment.

“It all happened so fast,” he whispers, “I didn’t really get a chance… so much changed, and I wish we could’ve talked about it, you know?”

“Yea,” she breathes, “I know. You had a lifetime stolen away from you, kid.” 

She’s not just talking about the five years that had been pulled out from under him. She thinks about the life that Tony had built for them here, the plans he’d made for them–all of them–that he didn’t get to see through to the end.

“He hugged me, in the middle of everything, and I almost thought… it felt like more than just… but then, when he, when he was dying, he didn’t say anything, and I know that’s not fair, but I… I don’t know what I’m trying to say.”

Pepper knows, though. She knows what Peter means. And she knows what her husband was trying to say to the kid, even if the words had failed him.

“He loved you,” she says simply, like stating an undeniable truth.

Peter shrinks into himself a little.

“Hey,” she says, pulling him back, “I know Tony well enough to know that he probably never said that in words. But I also know him well enough to promise you that it’s true. I learned early on that Tony is much better at showing love than he is at voicing it. It’s the way he is, and it doesn’t make his love any less real or valid.”

Her voice goes even softer, and she turns Peter around to face her because she needs him to hear this next part–because Tony needed him to hear this.

“He told me, once, that didn’t think he’d be able to rest until he could put a suit of armor around the world. I thought it was… a fever dream. But then I saw him look at you, right at the end, wrapped up in the suit he made for you. I saw him look at James, at me, safe and whole and protected, and I realized right then that he’d done it. For the first time in a long, long time, there was… something peaceful in his eyes. He put a suit of armor around his world, and he could finally rest, because we were going to be okay. Hurting, yes, and maybe a little broken, but we’d be okay.”

And then, after a long silence, she thinks she sees something peaceful come over Peter, too. 

The two of them sit there for a while, doing what Tony had always done in that same spot. They let the blissful quiet consume them until the world seems a little less loud and far away, until the broken pieces don’t feel as sharp.

“Pepper?” 

“Mhm?”

“I think… I think I loved him, too. Do you–do you think he knows that?”

Pepper might be imagining it, but a warmth seems to pierce through the cool night, shrouding both of them from the cold. 

“Yea, kiddo,” she leans down, pulling him into her until her smile is pressed against his hair, following his gaze still fixed on the horizon, “I think he does.”

“About what?”

She asks the question even though she already knows the answer. She knows exactly where his mind is as his gaze fixes over the horizon.

“Just,” he shrugs, gesturing out in to the wind, “y’know. About all of it.”

Her fingers trace gently across his shoulder blades in an action she’d seen Tony do many times before, the sensation both strange and familiar on Peter’s skin. 

“He always thought that you’d like it out here. He said that that brain of yours,” her fingers tap lightly on his forehead, “had a habit of getting a little too loud sometimes. You remind me of him, in a lot of ways.“

“I think… I think I loved him, too. Do you–do you think he knows that?”

Pepper might be imagining it, but a warmth seems to pierce through the cool night, shrouding both of them from the cold. 

“Yea, kiddo,” she leans down, pulling him into her until her smile is pressed against his hair, following his gaze still fixed on the horizon, “I think he does.”

trail.content_raw:
Pepper finds Peter on the dock, feet dangling over the wooden planks, staring out across the water. 

“Hey,” she says softly, smiling gently as she claims the spot next to him, “what’re you doing out here?”

“Hm,” he hums, “thinking, I guess.”

“About what?”

She asks the question even though she already knows the answer. She knows exactly where his mind is as his gaze fixes over the horizon.

“Just,” he shrugs, gesturing out in to the wind, “y’know. About all of it.”

Her fingers trace gently across his shoulder blades in an action she’d seen Tony do many times before, the sensation both strange and familiar on Peter’s skin. 

“He always thought that you’d like it out here. He said that that brain of yours,” her fingers tap lightly on his forehead, “had a habit of getting a little too loud sometimes. You remind me of him, in a lot of ways.“

[[MORE]]

They let the trickle of the evening waves fill the air for a moment.

“It all happened so fast,” he whispers, “I didn’t really get a chance… so much changed, and I wish we could’ve talked about it, you know?”

“Yea,” she breathes, “I know. You had a lifetime stolen away from you, kid.” 

She’s not just talking about the five years that had been pulled out from under him. She thinks about the life that Tony had built for them here, the plans he’d made for them–all of them–that he didn’t get to see through to the end.

“He hugged me, in the middle of everything, and I almost thought… it felt like more than just… but then, when he, when he was dying, he didn’t say anything, and I know that’s not fair, but I… I don’t know what I’m trying to say.”

Pepper knows, though. She knows what Peter means. And she knows what her husband was trying to say to the kid, even if the words had failed him.

“He loved you,” she says simply, like stating an undeniable truth.

Peter shrinks into himself a little.

“Hey,” she says, pulling him back, “I know Tony well enough to know that he probably never said that in words. But I also know him well enough to promise you that it’s true. I learned early on that Tony is much better at showing love than he is at voicing it. It’s the way he is, and it doesn’t make his love any less real or valid.”

Her voice goes even softer, and she turns Peter around to face her because she needs him to hear this next part–because Tony needed him to hear this.

“He told me, once, that didn’t think he’d be able to rest until he could put a suit of armor around the world. I thought it was… a fever dream. But then I saw him look at you, right at the end, wrapped up in the suit he made for you. I saw him look at James, at me, safe and whole and protected, and I realized right then that he’d done it. For the first time in a long, long time, there was… something peaceful in his eyes. He put a suit of armor around his world, and he could finally rest, because we were going to be okay. Hurting, yes, and maybe a little broken, but we’d be okay.”

And then, after a long silence, she thinks she sees something peaceful come over Peter, too. 

The two of them sit there for a while, doing what Tony had always done in that same spot. They let the blissful quiet consume them until the world seems a little less loud and far away, until the broken pieces don’t feel as sharp.

“Pepper?” 

“Mhm?”

“I think… I think I loved him, too. Do you–do you think he knows that?”

Pepper might be imagining it, but a warmth seems to pierce through the cool night, shrouding both of them from the cold. 

“Yea, kiddo,” she leans down, pulling him into her until her smile is pressed against his hair, following his gaze still fixed on the horizon, “I think he does.”

Pepper finds Peter on the dock, feet dangling over the wooden planks, staring out across the water. 

“Hey,” she says softly, smiling gently as she claims the spot next to him, “what’re you doing out here?”

“Hm,” he hums, “thinking, I guess.”

“About what?”

She asks the question even though she already knows the answer. She knows exactly where his mind is as his gaze fixes over the horizon.

“Just,” he shrugs, gesturing out in to the wind, “y’know. About all of it.”

Her fingers trace gently across his shoulder blades in an action she’d seen Tony do many times before, the sensation both strange and familiar on Peter’s skin. 

“He always thought that you’d like it out here. He said that that brain of yours,” her fingers tap lightly on his forehead, “had a habit of getting a little too loud sometimes. You remind me of him, in a lot of ways.“

They let the trickle of the evening waves fill the air for a moment.

“It all happened so fast,” he whispers, “I didn’t really get a chance… so much changed, and I wish we could’ve talked about it, you know?”

“Yea,” she breathes, “I know. You had a lifetime stolen away from you, kid.” 

She’s not just talking about the five years that had been pulled out from under him. She thinks about the life that Tony had built for them here, the plans he’d made for them–all of them–that he didn’t get to see through to the end.

“He hugged me, in the middle of everything, and I almost thought… it felt like more than just… but then, when he, when he was dying, he didn’t say anything, and I know that’s not fair, but I… I don’t know what I’m trying to say.”

Pepper knows, though. She knows what Peter means. And she knows what her husband was trying to say to the kid, even if the words had failed him.

“He loved you,” she says simply, like stating an undeniable truth.

Peter shrinks into himself a little.

“Hey,” she says, pulling him back, “I know Tony well enough to know that he probably never said that in words. But I also know him well enough to promise you that it’s true. I learned early on that Tony is much better at showing love than he is at voicing it. It’s the way he is, and it doesn’t make his love any less real or valid.”

Her voice goes even softer, and she turns Peter around to face her because she needs him to hear this next part–because Tony needed him to hear this.

“He told me, once, that didn’t think he’d be able to rest until he could put a suit of armor around the world. I thought it was… a fever dream. But then I saw him look at you, right at the end, wrapped up in the suit he made for you. I saw him look at James, at me, safe and whole and protected, and I realized right then that he’d done it. For the first time in a long, long time, there was… something peaceful in his eyes. He put a suit of armor around his world, and he could finally rest, because we were going to be okay. Hurting, yes, and maybe a little broken, but we’d be okay.”

The two of them sit there for a while, doing what Tony had always done in that same spot. They let the blissful quiet consume them until the world seems a little less loud and far away, until the broken pieces don’t feel as sharp.

“Pepper?” 

“Mhm?”

“I think… I think I loved him, too. Do you–do you think he knows that?”

Pepper might be imagining it, but a warmth seems to pierce through the cool night, shrouding both of them from the cold. 

“Yea, kiddo,” she leans down, pulling him into her until her smile is pressed against his hair, following his gaze still fixed on the horizon, “I think he does.”

Pepper finds Peter on the dock, feet dangling over the wooden planks, staring out across the water. 

“Hey,” she says softly, smiling gently as she claims the spot next to him, “what’re you doing out here?”

“Hm,” he hums, “thinking, I guess.”

“About what?”

She asks the question even though she already knows the answer. She knows exactly where his mind is as his gaze fixes over the horizon.

“Just,” he shrugs, gesturing out in to the wind, “y’know. About all of it.”

Her fingers trace gently across his shoulder blades in an action she’d seen Tony do many times before, the sensation both strange and familiar on Peter’s skin. 

“He always thought that you’d like it out here. He said that that brain of yours,” her fingers tap lightly on his forehead, “had a habit of getting a little too loud sometimes. You remind me of him, in a lot of ways.“
